column4: You don't use '$' in front of variable names when setting them.
good point
my mistake
No. And it's not generally a good idea to use --force-yes or to try to ignore dependencies. What are you trying to accomplish?
install a package that says   creepy: Depends: python (< 2.6) but 2.6.2-0ubuntu1 is to be installed, even though both python 2.5 and python 2.6 are installed

and its dependency line looks like this:  Depends: python (>= 2.5), python (<< 2.6), python-support (>= 0.7.1), osm-gps-map, python-simplejson, python-osmgpsmap (>= 0.7), python-beautifulsoup, python-pyexiv2, python-configobj, python-setuptools
What is creepy?
http://freshmeat.net/projects/creepy
A research tool
I just tried adding the ppa on my 10.10 system and installing creepy has no dependency problem here.
yeah...trying to install it on 9.04 here
9.04 is no longer supported.
yeah...everyone keeps telling me that
That's because 1: You shouldn't be running an OS without security updates and 2: "No longer supported" means that we don't support it.
w/o security updates is relative, considering it's on a closed network, without internet
Why are you using 9.04 still?
That still doesn't change point #2. We don't support unsupported releases.
because the platform is stable on 9.04, and we haven't worked the kinks out of 10.04 yet
there's a few kinks with plymouth, gdm/xdm and 10.04 for our autoinstaller for pxeboot-based installs
If you want to use 9.04 you're on your own. We can probably help you with getting the kinks worked out with 10.04 though.
yeah...unfortunately i'm not the one that gets to triage what's important and what's not for our product lifecycle
upgrading to 10.04 is important, but it's about 30 tasks down from the top of the mole hill right now
Unfortunately your corporate policies do not change this channel's policies. We do not support 9.04 here. Period.
ah...thought that was just a ubuntu policy, not necessarily a channel policy
